item.title: Felisa add a quote by Roald Dahl
item.description: "And above all, watch with glittering eyes the whole world around you because the greatest secrets are always hidden in the most unlikely places. Those who don't believe in magic will never find it." -- Roald Dahl

item.title: Felisa add a quote by George Orwell
item.description: "On the whole human beings want to be good, but not too good, and not quite all the time." -- George Orwell

item.title: Felisa add a quote by William Nicholson
item.description: "We read to know we're not alone." -- William Nicholson

item.title: Felisa add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "No book is really worth reading at the age of ten which is not equally – and often far more – worth reading at the age of fifty and beyond." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Kingsley Amis
item.description: "Consciousness was upon him before he could get out of the way." -- Kingsley Amis

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Mark Twain
item.description: "History doesn't repeat itself, but it does rhyme." -- Mark Twain

item.title: Felisa add a quote by mark twain
item.description: "But who prays for Satan? Who, in eighteen centuries, has had the common humanity to pray for the one sinner that needed it most?" -- mark twain

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Roald Dahl
item.description:
"She might even be your lovely school-teacher who is reading these words to you at this very moment. Look carefully at that teacher. Perhaps she is smiling at the absurdity of such a suggestion. Don't let that put you off. It could be part of cleverness.
I am not, of course, telling you for one second that your teacher actually is a witch. All I am saying is that she might be one. It is most unlikely. But--here comes the big "but"--not impossible." -- Roald Dahl

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Vladimir Nabokov
item.description: "You can always count on a murderer for a fancy prose style." -- Vladimir Nabokov

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Vladimir Nabokov
item.description: "We all have such fateful objects -- it may be a recurrent landscape in one case, a number in another -- carefully chosen by the gods to attract events of specific significance for us: here shall John always stumble; there shall Jane's heart always break." -- Vladimir Nabokov

item.title: Felisa add a quote by E.B. White
item.description: "Be obscure clearly." -- E.B. White

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Kingsley Amis
item.description: "... all his faces were designed to express rage or loathing. Now that something had happened which really deserved a face, he had none to celebrate it with. As a kind of token, he made his Sex Life in Ancient Rome face." -- Kingsley Amis

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Lester Bangs
item.description: "The first mistake of art is to assume that it's serious." -- Lester Bangs

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Sarah Vowell
item.description: "If I looked in the mirror someday and saw no dark circles under my eyes, I would probably look better. I just wouldn't look like me. " -- Sarah Vowell

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Graham Greene
item.description: "And when we love our sin then we are damned indeed." -- Graham Greene

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Sarah Vowell
item.description: "When I think about my relationship with America, I feel like a battered wife: Yeah, he knocks me around a lot, but boy, he sure can dance." -- Sarah Vowell

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Graham Greene
item.description: "The sense of unhappiness is so much easier to convey than that of happiness. In misery we seem aware of our own existence, even though it may be in the form of a monstrous egotism: this pain of mine is individual, this nerve that winces belongs to me and to no other. But happiness annihilates us: we lose our identity." -- Graham Greene

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Dorothy Sayers
item.description: "She couldn't have found anything nastier to say if she had thought it out with both hands for a fortnight." -- Dorothy Sayers

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Ernest Hemingway
item.description: "There is nothing to writing. All you do is sit down at a typewriter and bleed." -- Ernest Hemingway

item.title: Felisa add a quote by W. Somerset Maugham
item.description: "The great tragedy of life is not that men perish, but that they cease to love." -- W. Somerset Maugham

item.title: Felisa add a quote by W. Somerset Maugham
item.description: "There are three rules for writing a novel. Unfortunately, no one knows what they are." -- W. Somerset Maugham

item.title: Felisa add a quote by W. Somerset Maugham
item.description: "Only a mediocre person is always at his best. " -- W. Somerset Maugham

item.title: Felisa add a quote by W. Somerset Maugham
item.description: "Cronshaw stopped for a moment to drink. He had pondered for twenty years the problem whether he loved liquor because it made him talk or whether he loved conversation because it made him thirsty." -- W. Somerset Maugham

item.title: Felisa add a quote by W. Somerset Maugham
item.description: "I can imagine no more comfortable frame of mind for the conduct of life than a humorous resignation. " -- W. Somerset Maugham

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Dorothy Parker
item.description: "If you want to know what God thinks of money, just look at the people he gave it to." -- Dorothy Parker

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Sylvia Plath
item.description: "Kiss me, and you will see how important I am." -- Sylvia Plath

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Quentin R. Bufogle
item.description: "99% of all problems can be solved by money -- and for the other 1% there's alcohol." -- Quentin R. Bufogle

item.title: Felisa add a quote by John Donne
item.description: "Be thine own palace, or the world's thy jail." -- John Donne

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Graham Greene
item.description: "Like some wines our love could neither mature nor travel." -- Graham Greene

item.title: Felisa add a quote by Graham Greene
item.description: "Writing is a form of therapy; sometimes I wonder how all those who do not write, compose, or paint can manage to escape the madness, melancholia, the panic and fear which is inherent in a human situation." -- Graham Greene
